1.text: And yet, I pray thee, O Job, Hear my speech and to all my words give ear.

2.text: Lo, I pray thee, I have opened my mouth, My tongue hath spoken in the palate.

3.text: Of the uprightness of my heart are my sayings, And knowledge have my lips clearly spoken.

4.text: The Spirit of God hath made me, And the breath of the Mighty doth quicken me.

5.text: If thou art able—answer me, Set in array before me—station thyself.

6.text: Lo, I am, according to thy word, for God, From the clay I—I also, have been formed.

7.text: Lo, my terror doth not frighten thee, And my burden on thee is not heavy.

8.text: Surely—thou hast said in mine ears, And the sounds of words I hear:

9.text: Pure am I, without transgression, Innocent am I, and I have no iniquity.

10.text: Lo, occasions against me He doth find, He doth reckon me for an enemy to Him,

11.text: He doth put in the stocks my feet, He doth watch all my paths.’

12.text: Lo, in this thou hast not been righteous, I answer thee, that greater is God than man.

13.text: Wherefore against Him hast thou striven, When for all His matters He answereth not?

14.text: For once doth God speak, and twice, (He doth not behold it.)

15.text: In a dream—a vision of night, In the falling of deep sleep on men, In slumberings on a bed.

16.text: Then He uncovereth the ear of men, And for their instruction sealeth:

17.text: To turn aside man from doing, And pride from man He concealeth.

18.text: He keepeth back his soul from corruption, And his life from passing away by a dart.

19.text: And he hath been reproved With pain on his bed, And the strife of his bones is enduring.

20.text: And his life hath nauseated bread, And his soul desirable food.

21.text: His flesh is consumed from being seen, And high are his bones, they were not seen!

22.text: And draw near to the pit doth his soul, And his life to those causing death.

23.text: If there is by him a messenger, An interpreter—one of a thousand, To declare for man his uprightness:

24.text: Then He doth favour him and saith, ‘Ransom him from going down to the pit, I have found an atonement.’

25.text: Fresher is his flesh than a child’s, He returneth to the days of his youth.

26.text: He maketh supplication unto God, And He accepteth him. And he seeth His face with shouting, And He returneth to man His righteousness.

27.text: He looketh on men, and saith, ‘I sinned, And uprightness I have perverted, And it hath not been profitable to me.

28.text: He hath ransomed my soul From going over into the pit, And my life on the light looketh.’

29.text: Lo, all these doth God work, Twice—thrice with man,

30.text: To bring back his soul from the pit, To be enlightened with the light of the living.

31.text: Attend, O Job, hearken to me, Keep silent, and I—I do speak.

32.text: If there are words—answer me, Speak, for I have a desire to justify thee.

33.text: If there are not—hearken thou to me, Keep silent, and I teach thee wisdom.
